author: FrÃ©dÃ©ric Marsaly
title: A 95% les membres du syndicat ont rejetÃ© lâ€™offre de Boeing
text:
Bien que lâ€™accord proposÃ© par Boeing au syndicat Â« Aerospace Machinists District 751 Â» a Ã©tÃ© largement saluÃ© comme une avancÃ©e en apparence suffisante pour Ã©viter un conflit social majeur au sein du constructeur aÃ©ronautique, il a Ã©tÃ© rejetÃ© Ã  95% par un vote des membres de lâ€™organisation et 96% ont votÃ© pour la grÃ¨ve. 33 000 travailleurs se prÃ©parent donc Ã  dÃ©brayer dÃ¨s aujourdâ€™hui.
Dans sa proposition, la direction de Boeing promettait de construire le futur 797 dans la rÃ©gion de Seattle ou de Portland histoire dâ€™assurer une activitÃ© soutenue Ã  ces travailleurs spÃ©cialisÃ©s, satisfaisant ainsi une revendication importante du puissant syndicat. NÃ©anmoins la proposition dâ€™augmenter les salaires de 25% sur quatre ans a Ã©tÃ© jugÃ©e insuffisante par rapport aux 40% rÃ©clamÃ©s, que dâ€™autres organisations sont parvenues Ã  obtenir lors de nÃ©gociations dans dâ€™autres entreprises du secteur aÃ©ronautique. Dâ€™autres points de blocage portaient sur les couvertures santÃ© et retraite des employÃ©s pour lesquelles Boeing avait choisi dâ€™affecter dâ€™importants budgets supplÃ©mentaires.
MÃªme si certains reconnaissent que les propositions de Boeing Ã©taient les plus gÃ©nÃ©reuses proposÃ©es depuis longtemps, il semble que la compagnie paye au prix fort une dÃ©cennie de faible augmentation des salaires et surtout la fin de plans de pensions trÃ¨s favorables pour les nouveaux entrants de la compagnie.
Ce mouvement social qui pourrait dÃ©buter aujourdâ€™hui mÃªme, pourrait avoir des consÃ©quences sur lâ€™ensemble des sites industriels du constructeur aÃ©ronautique et menace de ralentir la montÃ©e en cadence de la production. Le nouveau CEO de Boeing espÃ©rait atteindre 38 Boeing 737 mensuels dâ€™ici la fin de lâ€™annÃ©e alors que la compagnie nâ€™en a livrÃ© que 137 sur les 6 premiers mois de 2024 (70 au second trimestre). Le coÃ»t de la grÃ¨ve pourrait donc atteindre le milliard de Dollars par mois car elle va, mÃ©caniquement, ralentir drastiquement la production des avions !
En 2008, les ouvriers de Boeing avaient dÃ©clenchÃ© un mouvement social qui avait durÃ© 57 jours.
Jon Holden, prÃ©sident de la branche du Syndicat chez Boeing a commentÃ© les rÃ©sultats du vote interne au sein de son organisation en annonÃ§ant Â« nous seront de retour Ã  la table des nÃ©gociations pour faire avancer les points que nos membres jugent importants Â» quant Ã  Boeing Â« Nous restons dÃ©terminÃ©s Ã  rÃ©tablir nos relations avec nos employÃ©s et le syndicat Â».
Pour Boeing, le vol en zone de turbulences sâ€™intensifie !

author: Dan Lampariello | CBS13 I-Team
title: chevron-right
text: MEXICO, Maine (WGME) -- The aftermath of last week's devastating storm still being felt in the western Maine mountains. In the Town of Mexico, the storm brought the swift river into the streets flooding homes and businesses, including the town's post office. "I just came to mail a letter and was quite surprised that it's still not open yet because of all the damage," said Nora Downs. It's unclear how severe the flooding damage inside the post office was but facility has been closed since December 18th. Those who live in and around the small town say they often rely on this post office and that it's normally busy. "I come here a lot," said Julie Melanson. "If I'm going that way I go to Rumford and if I go this way I go to Mexico. I have options but a lot of people don't have those kind of options." ALSO READ | [MaineDOT foresees weeks of work and multimillion-dollar cost for storm repair](https://wgme.com/news/local/mainedot-foresees-weeks-of-work-and-multimillion-dollar-cost-for-storm-repair-maine-wind-flooding-rain-power-outages#) ALSO READ | [ 'It's very important': Search continues for irreplaceable items taken down river during flooding in Lewiston](https://wgme.com/news/local/its-very-important-search-continues-for-irreplaceable-items-taken-down-river-during-flooding-in-lewiston-maine-veterans-memorial-park-casket-floodwaters-rain-wind-storm-androscoggin-river#) In a letter to customer last week, the U.S. Postal Service said the building will remain closed while they "evaluate potential solutions." Some in town fear that could mean the post office may never reopen but the USPS says no final decision has been made on that front yet. In the meantime, as the community in Mexico continues to recover from the impacts of the flood, including the deaths of two people in town, the hope is that even small things like having an open post office can help them move forward. "I hope people will work together to help each other and mend this sad situation," Downs said.

author: Redaktion
title: â€žNova Rock"-Festival in Ã–sterreich: PlÃ¶tzlich wird es ganz leise
text:
Das â€žNova Rockâ€œ-Festival startete trotz bedrÃ¼ckender UmstÃ¤nde. Nach dem schrecklichen Amoklauf in Graz gedachten die Besucher den Opfern zum Festivalstart am Mittwoch (11. Juni 2025) mit einer Schweigeminute. Veranstalter Ewald Tatar hielt eine Ansprache und lieÃŸ den gesamten Veranstaltungsort kurz verstummen. Die Festivalgemeinde zeigte Zusammenhalt und setzte ein starkes Signal der SolidaritÃ¤t.
Die Ã¤uÃŸeren Bedingungen waren optimal: angenehme Temperaturen, kein Staub, strahlender Sonnenschein. Das â€žNova Rockâ€œ-Festival bot damit den perfekten Rahmen fÃ¼r den Start ins musikalische Wochenende. Nur die HauptbÃ¼hne und die Red Bull Stage waren am ersten Tag in Betrieb, wÃ¤hrend die Red Stage eine Pause hatte.
++ Drama bei â€žRock am Ringâ€œ: â€žSind am Boden zerstÃ¶rtâ€œ ++
Schweigeminute auf dem â€žNova Rockâ€œ
Die Band Seven Hours After Violet beeindruckte mit einem energiegeladenen Auftritt. Besonders Shavo Odadjian, bekannt als Bassist von System Of A Down, genoss die neue musikalische Freiheit. â€žEs fÃ¼hlt sich so an wie frÃ¼her bei System Of A Down, als wir angefangen habenâ€œ, erklÃ¤rte er im GesprÃ¤ch mit der Ã¶sterreichischen â€žKronen Zeitungâ€œ.
++ Rock am Ring: Abreise in vollem Gange â€“ â€žWas zur HÃ¶lle habt ihr euch gedacht?â€œ ++
Zur Schweigeminute versammelten sich rund 40.000 Menschen, um gemeinsam der Opfer des Amoklaufs von Graz zu gedenken. â€žDer Schmerz Ã¼ber den gestrigen, unfassbaren Amoklauf in Graz sitzt noch bei uns allen sehr tiefâ€œ, betonte Tatar. Der Moment wurde von den Besuchern diszipliniert und respektvoll wahrgenommen â€“ eine eindrucksvolle Geste.
Neben Acts wie Spiritbox und Korn prÃ¤sentierte das Nova Rock eine gut abgestimmte Mischung aus etablierten KÃ¼nstlern und Newcomern. Die Festivalbesucher genossen die einzigartigen Momente und bewiesen, dass sowohl Eskapismus als auch SolidaritÃ¤t Teil des Nova-Rock-Spirits sind.
Dieser Artikel wurde teils mit maschineller UnterstÃ¼tzung erstellt und vor der VerÃ¶ffentlichung von der Redaktion sorgfÃ¤ltig geprÃ¼ft.
topics: War, Conflict and Unrest->act of terror

author: kake.com
title: Walmart recalls magnetic balls after CPSC warns of choking and injury hazards - KAKE
text:
By Ramishah Maruf, CNN
New York (CNN) â€” Regulators have issued a recall for high-powered magnetic balls after the US Consumer Product Safety Commission issued several warnings for the toy kits, citing the risk of injury or even death.
Walmart recalled the â€œRelax 5mm Science Kit, Large Hematite Magnets Magnetic Stones Building Blocks,â€ sold exclusively on the site through Joybuy.
Earlier in December, CPSC said these magnets, often marketed for children, are small enough to fit into the CPSCâ€™s small parts cylinder (which simulates the width of a childâ€™s throat), and are also magnetically stronger than permitted. If swallowed, the high-powered magnets can attract to each other or to other metals inside the digestive system, leading to â€œperforations, twisting and/or blockage of the intestines, infection, blood poisoning and death.â€
The agency broadly estimated 2,500 emergency room visits over magnet ingestions from 2017-2021 and seven deaths, two of which were outside of the United States.
The recall affects about 4,240 units. The CPSC said customers should take away the balls from children immediately and contact Joybuy for a pre-paid label to return the recalled products for a full refund. The toy kit was sold from February 2022 through April 2023 for between $14 and $15 and is made of small magnetic balls in purple, black, green, blue, orange and red.
The-CNN-Wire

author: EFE
title: Cientos de brasileÃ±os y leyendas del fÃºtbol despiden al â€œViejo Loboâ€ Zagallo | EL ESPECTADOR
text: Cientos de brasileÃ±os y algunas leyendas de la selecciÃ³n de ese paÃ­s despidieron a Mario Jorge Lobo Zagallo, el Ãºnico con cuatro Copas del Mundo en el universo del fÃºtbol, quien falleciÃ³ el viernes y fue sepultado este domingo en RÃ­o de Janeiro. Vea: Con golazo de Luis DÃ­az el Liverpool derrotÃ³ al Arsenal, por la Copa FA (Video) El â€œViejo Loboâ€, quien tenÃ­a la salud quebrantada desde hace una dÃ©cada, falleciÃ³ la medianoche del pasado viernes a los 92 aÃ±os en un hospital de RÃ­o de Janeiro, ciudad en la que comenzÃ³ su carrera en el fÃºtbol como puntero izquierdo del club AmÃ©rica. La velaciÃ³n fue en la sede de la ConfederaciÃ³n BrasileÃ±a de FÃºtbol (CBF), en cuya fachada lucÃ­a un cartel en el que se leÃ­a â€œZagallo Eternoâ€, una frase con â€œ13 letrasâ€, el nÃºmero preferido del â€œViejo Loboâ€, quien admitÃ­a ser supersticioso como pocos. Junto al ataÃºd, una estatua de cera de 1,70 metros de altura, que lo muestra con su uniforme de entrenador, y las cinco Copas del Mundo obtenidas por Brasil, de las cuales cuatro fueron ganadas por selecciones que tuvieron al â€œViejo Loboâ€ entre sus integrantes. Fueron en Suecia 1958 y Chile 1962 como jugador, en MÃ©xico 1970 como entrenador y en Estados Unidos 1994 como coordinador tÃ©cnico. Pese a la importancia de Zagallo, pocas personalidades del fÃºtbol comparecieron. Entre ellos, Zinho, Grafite, Mazinho, Gilmar Rinaldi, Mauro Silva, CafÃº y Bebeto, exjugadores de la selecciÃ³n brasileÃ±a y que en algÃºn momento tuvieron a Zagallo como entrenador. Lea tambiÃ©n: Los eventos deportivos que le quedaron grandes a Colombia Bebeto, quien brillÃ³ como delantero en EspaÃ±a con el Deportivo La CoruÃ±a y el Sevilla, recordÃ³ a Zagallo como \"un tipo que nunca se desanimaba\" y afirmÃ³ que su \"mayor referencia y maestro\" en el fÃºtbol. \"Un tipo siempre positivo, que contagiaba en el vestuario\" y \"alentaba a sus jugadores como nadie\", agregÃ³ Bebeto, campeÃ³n mundial en Estados Unidos 1994. TambiÃ©n estuvieron el exseleccionador y actual entrenador de Flamengo Adenor Leonardo Bachi \"Tite\", junto a directivos de los clubes Botafogo, Flamengo, Fluminense y Vasco da Gama, los cuatro grandes de RÃ­o de Janeiro en los que Zagallo actuÃ³ como jugador o tÃ©cnico. El presidente de la CBF, Ednaldo Rodrigues, valorÃ³ el \"gigantesco legado\" de Zagallo para el fÃºtbol mundial y anunciÃ³ que la entidad prepararÃ¡ \"una serie de homenajes\" para \"honrar su memoria\" durante todo este aÃ±o. Lea: FalleciÃ³ Mario Zagallo, leyenda de Brasil y ganador de cuatro Copas del Mundo Tras el velatorio, el ataÃºd, cubierto con banderas de la CBF, la FIFA y la Conmebol, fue transportado en un camiÃ³n de Bomberos hasta el cementerio SÃ£o JoÃ£o Batista, en el barrio de Botafogo. AllÃ­, esas tres banderas fueron sustituidas por una de Brasil y el â€œViejo Loboâ€ fue sepultado en una ceremonia reservada para sus familiares y amigos mÃ¡s Ã­ntimos, que lo despidieron con una larga salva de aplausos. ðŸš´ðŸ»âš½ðŸ€ Â¿Lo Ãºltimo en deportes?: Todo lo que debe saber del deporte mundial estÃ¡ en El Espectador

author: NBC New York
title: El plan de la tarifa por congestiÃ³n en Manhattan podrÃ­a volver antes de lo esperado
text:
SegÃºn un nuevo informe, las finanzas de la MTA estÃ¡n en serios aprietos, por lo que el controvertido plan de fijaciÃ³n de precios por congestiÃ³n podrÃ­a volver a tenerse en cuenta antes de lo esperado, y la gobernadora Kathy Hochul parece estar casi lista para levantar la pausa que implementÃ³.
El contralor del estado de Nueva York, Thomas DiNapoli, afirmÃ³ en un informe que el aumento de los costos de las horas extra y la lenta recuperaciÃ³n del nÃºmero de pasajeros del metro a los niveles previos a la pandemia han supuesto un gran problema para la agencia de transporte. Sin los fondos de fijaciÃ³n de precios por congestiÃ³n con los que contaba la MTA, se enfrenta a un dÃ©ficit presupuestario de al menos 176 millones de dÃ³lares, que podrÃ­a aumentar a $1,500 millones.
El informe encontrÃ³ una â€œnueva incertidumbreâ€ y un riesgo para el presupuesto operativo del estado, ya que la MTA tenÃ­a previsto tener $15,000 millones de dÃ³lares, pero ahora no se han contabilizado.
â€œSe podrÃ­a ver una espiral descendenteâ€, dijo DiNapoli. â€œTanto si estÃ¡s a favor de la tarificaciÃ³n por congestiÃ³n como si estÃ¡s en contra, tienes que conseguir los ingresosâ€.
Para aumentar la incertidumbre, dijo DiNapoli, estÃ¡ el hecho de que una agencia federal reciba la aprobaciÃ³n final, lo que se produce cuando el control polÃ­tico estÃ¡ en juego el dÃ­a de las elecciones.
â€œDependiendo del resultado de las elecciones presidenciales y de quÃ© administraciÃ³n estÃ© en el poder, Â¿podrÃ­a eso afectar a la aprobaciÃ³n federal para esto?â€, preguntÃ³ DiNapoli.
El contralor dijo que, a menos que la MTA identifique la financiaciÃ³n, los pasajeros pueden enfrentarse a tarifas mÃ¡s altas o a un servicio reducido. El presidente de la MTA dijo que ya habÃ­a sido transparente al respecto antes de que se emitiera el informe de los contralores.
â€œNo creo que haya nada ahÃ­ que me alarme. Somos muy conscientes de elloâ€, dijo el presidente de la MTA, Janno Lieber.
Cuando los funcionarios de la MTA aprobaron por primera vez la tarificaciÃ³n por congestiÃ³n, se consideraron varios precios de peaje posibles. Ese rango terminÃ³ siendo bastante considerable: desde $9 a $23 para conducir hasta Manhattan por debajo de la calle 61 en horas pico.
Finalmente, se acordÃ³ un precio intermedio, en lo que parecÃ­a un compromiso. Pero luego la gobernadora Hochul presionÃ³ la pausa.
â€œQuince dÃ³lares para instituir la tarificaciÃ³n por congestiÃ³n era demasiado altoâ€, dijo la gobernadora el miÃ©rcoles.
Hochul agregÃ³ que se estÃ¡ acercando a levantar la pausa sobre el controvertido plan. Se espera que la claridad llegue a fines de 2024.
â€œPresentamos un plan para fines de aÃ±o, como nos comprometimos. Nos estamos acercando a ese plazoâ€, dijo Hochul.
Si se inicia la tarificaciÃ³n por congestiÃ³n, la gobernadora indicÃ³ que podrÃ­a ser con un peaje mÃ¡s bajo. Por ejemplo, el precio podrÃ­a bajar a $9 en lugar de $15, que estÃ¡ dentro del rango que los funcionarios federales ya aprobaron.
Hochul tambiÃ©n dijo que su plan de fin de aÃ±o abordarÃ­a otras necesidades financieras de la MTA con un presupuesto de capital multimillonario.

author: Taylor Telford
title: New graduates question their degree as they face tougher job market, AI - The Washington Post
text:
Ever since she graduated a year ago with a degree in computer science, Maggie Chen, 23, has been searching for her first real job. The process has been grueling and impersonal, she said, involving a lot of ghosting and rejection, which at times has made her â€œa bit depressed and demotivated.â€
Mostly, â€œlooking on LinkedIn just makes me feel sad,â€ said Chen, who switched to computer science from biochemistry halfway through her undergraduate studies at the University of California at Davis after she got into computers early in the pandemic. Tech appealed to her because it seemed stable and full of opportunity â€” and because she wanted to be done with school after completing her bachelorâ€™s degree.
For Chen, a first-generation college student, the â€œguilt of being dependentâ€ on her parents after graduation has been â€œvery awful,â€ despite how supportive they are. They encouraged her to follow in the footsteps of friends who are pursuing more advanced degrees to better their chances on the job market, but she is wary about spending more time and money on school.
â€œEverybody tells you, â€˜Just get a college degree and youâ€™ll get a jobâ€™ and itâ€™ll make things easier,â€ Chen said. Now, â€œa masterâ€™s is the new bachelorâ€™s, I guess.â€
Chen is among the growing numbers of graduates facing a bumpy transition to professional life as they contend with one of the toughest job markets in years for people in their 20s. The unemployment rate for college graduates ages 22 to 27 jumped to 5.3 percent in the past six months ending in May, up from 4.4 percent for the same period a year earlier, according to a Washington Post analysis of Bureau of Labor Statistics data. College graduates in that age group usually have a lower unemployment rate than workers without degrees, but their advantage now is as small as it has been at any point since at least 1994.
As summer heats up, grads are peppering social media with frustrated posts about the job search. In interviews, young workers said they are disillusioned with unresponsive recruiters and employers, ghost postings and AI slop on jobsites. Rejection after rejection has left many grads still struggling to find their feet more than a year after graduation, forcing some to question the value of their degrees and pivot, while others take gambles in hopes of working in their chosen fields.
For now, Chen has an internship with a start-up in New York that she hopes will lead somewhere. But she knows sheâ€™s at a disadvantage vying for full-time roles in the current market.
â€œEverybody being laid off is applying to the same positions as me,â€ Chen said. â€œThey obviously have more experience, so Iâ€™m at a loss, I guess.â€
Shrinking opportunities
Growth among entry-level jobs across tech, finance and consulting â€” the top industries attracting graduates â€” has slowed significantly in the past few years, according to data from Revelio Labs, a workforce analytics company: Since the early days of the pandemic, employers have been adding fewer entry-level positions compared with more-experienced roles. Entry-level openings in these fields are down 33 percent compared with 2015, Revelioâ€™s data shows. In contrast, non-entry-level openings rose 67 percent in the same period.
Lisa Simon, chief economist at Revelio Labs, said that â€œclassic graduate programs in big companies just seem to be recruiting lessâ€ as higher interest rates and inflationary pressures weigh on budgets. In this market, â€œwe are seeing an increasing value put on experience and expertise in a lot of areas,â€ she added.
Fluctuating trade policies and political uncertainty also are contributing to a â€œreally, really cautious hiring environmentâ€ for employers, Simon said. Meanwhile, early-career roles are â€œseeing the biggest declines from AI exposure,â€ in part because they often involve the kinds of â€œexecutable tasks that AI tends to be fairly good at.â€
â€œThereâ€™s a lot going on, and, unfortunately, it impacts entry-level jobs the most,â€ Simon said.
Manav Raj, an assistant professor of management at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, said he has noticed â€œa little more consternation about the job searchâ€ from his students. Among those working on their MBAs, thereâ€™s a sense of diminished job opportunities, Raj said.
Compared with what he encountered after graduating in 2015, the entry-level market today is â€œvery, very different,â€ he added.
The reasons are myriad, Raj continued, pointing to hiring pullbacks in tech and other industries, as well as inflation and tariff uncertainty weighing on corporate budgets. And the embrace of AI is â€œchanging the way companies are making these investmentsâ€ in their workforces, he said.
â€œThings have changed really quickly,â€ Raj said. â€œThey may have entered these programs or career paths in an environment where things looked more vibrant. Now thereâ€™s this sense of uncertainty.â€
Razed pathways
Katie Donivanâ€™s first job was scooping ice cream. She never expected that more than a year after graduating summa cum laude with a journalism degree from San Diego State University, sheâ€™d be back where she started.
Donivan, a California native who hoped to be an arts and fashion writer, knew sheâ€™d be â€œfighting tooth and nailâ€ in a media landscape scarred by layoffs and shuttered publications. But these days, it feels to her as if the main barrier is that â€œitâ€™s so hard to convince somebody you can write better than AI.â€ AI-assisted writing tools are everywhere, she noted, and she worries that adoption of these tools in newsrooms could be diminishing entry-level roles.
Employment of news analysts, reporters and other journalists is projected to decline by 3 percent from 2023 to 2033, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Donivan has pivoted to applying to marketing and PR roles, but finding even a part-time job has been a challenge. Reluctantly, she has started using AI tools to assist with her job applications to better her chances.
â€œIf I donâ€™t hop on the bandwagon with everybody else, I will get left behind,â€ Donivan said.
Jaxon Gryder, who graduated in December from Grand Valley State University with a marketing degree, considered college â€œthe best timeâ€ of his life. But after more than 100 unsuccessful job applications on LinkedIn alone, the 23-year-old sometimes wonders whether college prepared him well enough for the professional world.
Gryder, who worked his way through undergrad, said he learned more from his side hustles working social media campaigns than he did from classes, which he felt were mostly â€œabout hearing about other peopleâ€™s experience.â€ He found it hard to translate the examples he encountered in class to the real world.
â€œTheyâ€™d give us a study, and the date was 2012, 2006, 1995,â€ Gryder said. â€œAnd Iâ€™d be, like, â€˜How is this relevant today?â€™â€
In job interviews, Gryder is beyond tired of hearing: â€œWe love you, but you donâ€™t have the experience.â€ He is optimistic his upcoming internship â€” his first â€” with a digital marketing company will help him land a full-time job or open up other opportunities. But for now, he is waiting tables at the same Italian sports bar in the Grand Rapids area where he worked to pay his way through school. His pay waxes and wanes with the crowds, and it has been stressful to operate without a financial safety net.
â€œI have that impostor syndromeâ€ Gryder said. â€œIf I get a job, am I going to be qualified enough? Am I going to know what to do?â€
For Daniela Macom, getting a foot in the door professionally meant taking â€œa leap of faith.â€ In June, about a year after she graduated from college with a marketing and communications degree, the 23-year-old drove from her home state of Texas to Southern California to start an unpaid internship with a public-relations company specializing in fashion and celebrity.
The gamble felt necessary to Macom after the year she spent applying unsuccessfully to scores of PR and marketing roles, along with internships paid and unpaid. To pay the bills, she worked at an insurance agency, which made her miserable.
â€œThe field I want to go into is kind of saturated right now, at least thatâ€™s what it seems like,â€ Macom said.
It was an uphill battle to convince her family that it was in the best interest of her career to quit a stable 9-to-5 job and uproot for an unpaid internship, Macom said. She often wonders whether sheâ€™s doing the right thing but said she didnâ€™t see another way to get her career off the ground.
â€œIt might be a huge waste of time, and, on top of that, I donâ€™t have a job, but at least Iâ€™m doing something,â€ Macom said. â€œThese companies want experience. Well, Iâ€™m gaining experience.â€
Andrew Van Dam contributed to this report.

author: Joseph (Joe) Drayton
title: Understanding the Benefits of Arbitration in Patent Disputes
text:
â€œThere is not a one-size-fits-all approach to including arbitration provisions, and contract terms should be creatively crafted to extend to any potential patent or other intellectual property dispute that may arise.â€
Arbitration, including international arbitration, can be a beneficial tool for the enforcement of patent portfolios, license agreements and infringement disputes. When entering into agreements/licenses (including commercial supplier, distributor and partnership agreements), parties may deem it useful to include an arbitration provision to resolve any disputes arising from those agreements. As such, parties can take advantage of the numerous benefits of international arbitration in the event of a dispute relating to intellectual property, in contrast to relying on district court proceedings.
Here are some of the key benefits of arbitration:
Confidentiality: Arbitrations can be kept confidential, and the parties can ensure that their disputes are not thrust into the public eye (as in district court litigation). Patent and other intellectual property disputes often involve highly confidential technology, business relationships, financial information and trade secrets. Having a private forumâ€”although the parties should still endeavor to enter a robust confidentiality agreementâ€”is advantageous.
Choice of Arbitrator: The parties may mutually choose one or more arbitrators to preside over the dispute, which allows the selection of candidates with a technical background and experience with patent litigation. Unlike in district court, where a judge is automatically assigned to a case and may not have requisite experience, parties in arbitration are free to mutually decide upon an appropriate arbitrator. To the extent the parties cannot agree, they can choose a three-arbitrator panel with each side selecting one arbitrator unilaterally and mutually agreeing upon the third.
Timing: Arbitrations are generally shorter in duration than litigation. The parties can set time frames within the arbitration agreement and can agree upon an appropriate case schedule. Thus, patent and related intellectual property disputes may be resolved more quickly in arbitration than in district court.
Flexibility: International arbitrations, for example, are inherently more flexible than district court litigation as parties are able to contract around traditional local rules. For example, the parties can agree upon choice of law provisions in arbitration agreements and have U.S. law applied even in certain foreign disputes. The parties may also agree to a cap or limitation on total damages that may be awarded, removing the risk to respondents of a jury awarding excessive damages. Additionally, parties can agree to limit or stagger the issues raised in arbitration or even agree to limit the scope of any ongoing dispute if the issues addressed in arbitration do not resolve the dispute entirely.
Reduced Expense: Arbitration is a cheaper alternative to litigation when the parties agree to minimize costs. For example, discovery in arbitration can be very targeted, especially if the parties agree to be governed by certain rules (such as the IBA rules on evidence). Often in arbitration, the parties limit written discovery and depositions in international arbitration are rare as witnesses instead provide a written statement.
The taking of evidence at arbitral hearings provides additional opportunities for cost reductions. For example, the taking of evidence is scheduled and parties can agree to a limited number of witnesses who will testify at the hearing. Usually, witnesses put forth affirmative testimony via a witness statement and are cross-examined at the hearing itself. This reduces cost and time by effectively eliminating direct examination and providing a witness statement to the arbitrators and opposing party in advance.
Another way in which expenses may be reduced in international arbitration as opposed to district court litigation is through the increased use of junior lawyers. Any preliminary hearings and conferences tend to be more informal and do not require a lead attorney to speakâ€”junior attorneys are provided with opportunities to argue their partyâ€™s positions and oversee discovery. Accordingly, attorneysâ€™ fees associated with arbitration are often lower than a district court case by comparison.
Post-Trial Briefing: Parties to international arbitrations are almost always given the opportunity to summarize their case in post-trial briefing. This is not often permitted in district court, especially in jury trials. Post-trial briefing may be an advantageous tool to summarize each partyâ€™s position and ensure all the facts are before the arbitral tribunal before adjudication.
Limited Opportunities for Appeal: Unlike district court litigation where appeals are widely available and frequently utilized, there is no right to appeal a final award in arbitration. Additionally, there are limited means by which a party may contest an award. This serves to reinforce the finality of arbitral decisions and further reduces overall costs by avoiding the risk of a lengthyâ€”and costlyâ€”appeal.
Enforcement: Enforcement of patent rights may be easier in arbitration, especially as it relates to enforcement of patents in foreign jurisdictions. The main vehicle of enforcement in international arbitration is the New York Convention; however, it does provide for a foreign court to refuse enforcement if the specific dispute is not arbitrable under that countryâ€™s laws. Even still, depending on where the parties are located and conduct business, an international arbitration may provide a mechanism for adjudicating wide-reaching patent rights (e.g., across an entire international patent portfolio) without having to litigate in each respective country.
These exemplary benefits are underscored by the ability to utilize international arbitration to decide a large number of inter-disciplinary disputes. For example, parties often arbitrate trade secret misappropriation claims, and these may inherently involve issues of patent infringement or validity. Inclusion of other claims, such as trade secrets claims, in patent arbitration can expand the potential for a damages recovery (if claimant) or open up your options for counterclaims (if respondent).
To ensure that you can take advantage of the many benefits of international arbitration, parties should consider including arbitration provisions in patent licenses, business contracts and settlement agreements. There is not a one-size-fits-all approach to including arbitration provisions, and contract terms should be creatively crafted to extend to any potential patent or other intellectual property dispute that may arise. By including arbitration provisions in technology licenses and other commercial agreements concerning patented technology, parties will be better suited to avail themselves of the benefits of international arbitration should any patent disputes arise in the future.
